div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Observation and imagination are the basic principles of all poetry . It is impossible to conceive a poetical work from which one of them is wholly absent . Observation without imagination makes for obviousness ; imagination without observation turns into nonsense . What marks the world 's greatest poetry is perhaps the presence in almost equal proportion of both these principles . But as a rule we find one of them predominating , and from this one-sided emphasis the poetry of the period derives its character as realistic or idealistic .

The poetry of the middle nineteenth century made a fetish of observation . It came as near excluding imagination as it could without ceasing entirely to be poetry . That such exaggeration should sooner or later result in a sharp reaction was natural . The change began during the eighties and gathered full headway in the early nineties . Imagination , so long scorned , came into its rights once more , and it is rapidly becoming the dominant note in the literary production of our own day .

The new movement has been called “ neo-romantic ” and “ symbolistic . ” Both these names apply , but neither of them exhausts the contents or meaning of the movement which received its first impetus from Ibsen and which later found its typical embodiment in Maeterlinck . From this movement came much of the inspiration that produced the poetical re-birth of Ireland out of which has sprung the man whom I have now the pleasure of introducing to American readers : a man with imagination as elfish as moonlight mist .

Edward John Moreton Drax Plunkett , Lord Dunsany , is the eighteenth member of his family to bear the title which gives him a place in the Irish peerage . He was born in 1878 and received his education at Eton and Sandhurst . In 1899 he succeeded his father to the title and the family estate in Meath , Ireland . During the South African war he served at the front with the Coldstream Guards . He is passionately fond of outdoor life and often spends the whole day in the saddle before sitting down at his desk to write late at night .

His work proves , however , that he is as fond of spiritual as of physical exercise , and that he is an inveterate traveller in those mysterious regions of the partly known or wholly unknown where the imagination alone can guide us . His first literary heroes were the brothers Grimm and Andersen . Then the Greek world of Olympians was revealed to him , making a lasting impression on his mind . But it was the Bible that gave him the limpid style which makes his most fantastic tales as real as government reports — or rather much more so . “ For years no style seemed to me natural but that of the Bible , ” he said not long ago , “ and I feared that I would never become a writer when I saw that other people did not use it . ”

For something like ten years he has been a pretty frequent and increasingly valued contributor to English and Anglo-Irish periodicals . He has previously published five volumes : “ The Gods of Pegana , ” 1905 ; “ Time and the Gods , ” 1906 ; “ The Sword of Welleran , ” 1908 ; “ A Dreamer 's Tales , ” 1910 ; and “ The Book of Wonder , ” 1912 . All are collections of prose pieces that defy accepted classifications . They are fairy tales and short stories and essays and prose poems at the same time .

The reader has only to take a brief glance at one of those works to make the astounding discovery that he is being introduced to worlds of which he has never heard before . Even the “ Arabian Nights ” have a clearly identifiable background of popular legend and myth . Nothing of the kind is to be found in the writings of Lord Dunsany . He may be said to have created a new mythology wholly his own . He is not only the master but the maker of the countries to which he takes us on such fascinating jaunts . His commonest name for them is the Edge of the World , but sometimes he speaks of them as the Lands of Wonder . This latter name is doubly significant , for the whole movement of which he forms such a striking manifestation has been defined as a “ renascence of wonder . ”

The names of places and persons appearing in the stories of Lord Dunsany are worth a study in themselves . There are hundreds of them , giving evidence of an inexhaustible imagination ; and each one of them is as aptly suggestive as if generations of men had been at work shaping them . To hear of Sardathion , the city built by the Gods of Old , is to see its domes of marble rising sky-high in the sunset-lighted air . To hear of Slith and Sippy and Slorg , the three thieves who went to the Edge of the World in quest of the Golden Box , is to feel as if one were dealing with historical characters like Aaron Burr or Chinese Gordon . And as we learn more about them , these fanciful creatures of Lord Dunsany 's brain assume still more familiar characteristics , as if they had been studied in some Irish village or English street . It is this fact that reveals one of the main secrets of Lord Dunsany 's appeal : that behind all his exuberant imagination lies a solid basis of observation , enabling him to endow the most impossible adventures with a homely and convincing air .

The five plays contained in the present volume have all been produced on the stage . “ The Golden Doom ” and “ The Gods of the Mountain ” have been staged most successfully at the Haymarket Theatre , London . “ King Argimenes ” and “ The Glittering Gate ” have been given by the Irish Players , and “ The Lost Silk Hat ” has been put on by Iden Payne at Manchester . In America , the first three have been in the repertoire of Stuart Walker 's Portmanteau Theatre , and “ The Glittering Gate ” has been given by the Neighborhood Players .

After seeing “ The Gods of the Mountain , ” Frank Harris wrote : “ It was one of the nights of my life ; the only play , I said to myself , which meant anything to me in twenty years or more . ” Without sharing the opinion of Mr. Harris about the dramatic output of the last twenty years , I share fully his enthusiasm in regard to the play that caused his remark . The note struck in it is so distinctly new as to make one gasp as under a sharp shock . But the surprise turns quickly into pleasure such as only the originality of genius can confer .

It is hard to define just what makes these plays what they are . But certain qualities are tangible . Their deep and rich symbolism is one . It is the kind of symbolism for which the advances of modern psychology had prepared us — the kind that is inseparable from life itself as we are only just beginning to understand it . Another quality is their capacity for suggesting at once the intimate unity and appalling vastness of life . In “ The Golden Doom ” the fate of an empire and a little boy 's desire for a new plaything become linked as facts of equal importance in the web of fate . In “ The Gods of the Mountain ” we meet with an atmosphere of fatality comparable only to that found in the Greek dramas . The crime of hybris , which to the Greeks was the “ unforgivable sin , ” is here made as real to us as it was to them .

set.p: But these remarks of mine about the inner significance of the plays should not tempt anybody into thinking them deficient in that element of formal perfection without which they could not be classed as works of art . They are , indeed , “ things of beauty , ” and their beauty inheres in their design as well as in their style . Through all of them the greatest possible economy of means has been observed , so that not a word , not a tone , not a gesture is wasted in obtaining the effect aimed at . The dialogue of Maeterlinck is suggested , but not more than suggested . The words spoken by the characters of Maeterlinck are often so vague as to be practically meaningless . The characters of Lord Dunsany speak as simply as those of Maeterlinck , but always sharply to the point ; there can be no mistaking of what they mean , and that meaning serves always to carry the action of the play forward . And each play of Lord Dunsany 's is an exciting adventure , conveying to the reader an exhilarating sense of motion without ever descending to old-fashioned stage tricks for the production of that sense . This means that they combine to an extraordinary degree the qualities which make separately for theatrical or literary success . EDWIN BJOeRKMAN .

div.head: THE FIRST ACT

stage.stage: Outside a city wall . Three beggars are seated upon the ground .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: These days are bad for beggary .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: They are bad .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: an older beggar but not graySome evil has befallen the rich ones of this city . They take no joy any longer in benevolence , but are become sour and miserly at heart . Alas for them ! I sometimes sigh for them when I think of this .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: Alas for them ! A miserly heart must be a sore affliction .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: A sore affliction indeed , and bad for our calling .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: reflectivelyThey have been thus for many months . What thing has befallen them ?

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: Some evil thing .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: There has been a comet come near to the earth of late and the earth has been parched and sultry so that the gods are drowsy and all those things that are divine in man , such as benevolence , drunkenness , extravagance , and song , have faded and died and have not been replenished by the gods .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: It has indeed been sultry .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: I have seen the comet o ’ nights .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: The gods are drowsy .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: If they awake not soon and make this city worthy again of our order I for one shall forsake the calling and buy a shop and sit at ease in the shade and barter for gain .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: You will keep a shop ?

div.stage: Enter Agmar and Slag . Agmar , though poorly dressed , is tall , imperious , and older than Ulf . Slag follows behind him .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Is this a beggar who speaks ?

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: Yes , master , a poor beggar .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: How long has the calling of beggary existed ?

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: Since the building of the first city , master .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: And when has a beggar ever followed a trade ? When has he ever haggled and bartered and sat in a shop ?

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: Why , he has never done so .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Are you he that shall be first to forsake the calling ?

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: Times are bad for the calling here .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: They are bad .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: So you would forsake the calling ?

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: The city is unworthy of our calling . The gods are drowsy and all that is divine in man is dead .To third beggarAre not the gods drowsy ?

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: They are drowsy in their mountains away at Marma . The seven green idols are drowsy . Who is this that rebukes us ?

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: Are you some great merchant , master ? Perhaps you will help a poor man that is starving .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: My master a merchant ! No , no . He is no merchant . My master is no merchant .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: I perceive that he is some lord in disguise . The gods have woken and have sent him to save us .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: No , no . You do not know my master . You do not know him .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: Is he the Soldan 's self that has come to rebuke us ?

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: I am a beggar , and an old beggar .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: with great prideThere is none like my master . No traveller has met with cunning like to his , not even those that come from AEthiopia .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: We make you welcome to our town , upon which an evil has fallen , the days being bad for beggary .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Let none who has known the mystery of roads or has felt the wind arising new in the morning , or who has called forth out of the souls of men divine benevolence , ever speak any more of any trade or of the miserable gains of shops and the trading men .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: I but spoke hastily , the times being bad .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: I will put right the times .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: There is nothing that my master cannot do .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: to SlagBe silent and attend to me . I do not know this city . I have travelled from far , having somewhat exhausted the city of Ackara .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: My master was three times knocked down and injured by carriages there , once he was killed and seven times beaten and robbed , and every time he was generously compensated . He had nine diseases , many of them mortal —

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Be silent , Slag .— Have you any thieves among the calling here ?

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: We have a few that we call thieves here , master , but they would scarcely seem thieves to you . They are not good thieves .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: I shall need the best thief you have .

div.stage: Enter two citizens richly clad , Illanaun and Oorander .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: Therefore we will send galleons to Ardaspes .

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: Right to Ardaspes through the silver gates .

div.stage: Agmar transfers the thick handle of his long staff to his left armpit , he droops on to it and it supports his weight ; he is upright no longer . His right arm hangs limp and useless . He hobbles up to the citizens imploring alms .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: I am sorry . I cannot help you . There have been too many beggars here and we must decline alms for the good of the town .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: sitting down and weepingI have come from far .

div.stage: Illanaun presently returns and gives Agmar a coin . Exit Illanaun . Agmar , erect again , walks back to the others .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: We shall need fine raiment ; let the thief start at once . Let it rather be green raiment .

sp.speaker: BEGGAR
sp.p: I will go and fetch the thief .Exit

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: We will dress ourselves as lords and impose upon the city .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: Yes , yes ; we will say we are ambassadors from a far land .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: And there will be good eating .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: in an undertone to UlfBut you do not know my master . Now that you have suggested that we shall go as lords , he will make a better suggestion . He will suggest that we should go as kings .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: Beggars as kings !

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: Ay . You do not know my master .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: to AgmarWhat do you bid us do ?

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: You shall first come by the fine raiment in the manner I have mentioned .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: And what then , master ?

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Why , then we shall go as gods .

sp.speaker: BEGGARS
sp.p: As gods !

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: As gods . Know you the land through which I have lately come in my wanderings ? Marma , where the gods are carved from green stone in the mountains . They sit all seven of them against the hills . They sit there motionless and travellers worship them .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: Yes , yes , we know those gods . They are much reverenced here , but they are drowsy and send us nothing beautiful .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: They are of green jade . They sit cross-legged with their right elbows resting on their left hands , the right forefinger pointing upward . We will come into the city disguised , from the direction of Marma , and will claim to be these gods . We must be seven as they are . And when we sit we must sit cross-legged as they do , with the right hand uplifted .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: This is a bad city in which to fall into the hands of oppressors , for the judges lack amiability here as the merchants lack benevolence , ever since the gods forgot them .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: In our ancient calling a man may sit at one street corner for fifty years doing the one thing , and yet a day may come when it is well for him to rise up and do another thing while the timorous man starves .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: Also it were well not to anger the gods .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Is not all life a beggary to the gods ? Do they not see all men always begging of them and asking alms with incense , and bells , and subtle devices ?

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: Yes , all men indeed are beggars before the gods .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Does not the mighty Soldan often sit by the agate altar in his royal temple as we sit at a street corner or by a palace gate ?

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: It is even so .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Then will the gods be glad when we follow the holy calling with new devices and with subtlety , as they are glad when the priests sing a new song .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: Yet I have a fear .

div.stage: Enter two men talking .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: to SlagGo you into the city before us and let there be a prophecy there which saith that the gods who are carven from green rock in the mountain shall one day arise in Marma and come here in the guise of men .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: Yes , master . Shall I make the prophecy myself ? Or shall it be found in some old document ?

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Let someone have seen it once in some rare document . Let it be spoken of in the market place .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: It shall be spoken of , master .

div.stage: Slag lingers . Enter Thief and Thahn .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: This is our thief .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: encouraginglyAh , he is a quick thief .

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: I could only procure you three green raiments , master . The city is not now well supplied with them ; moreover , it is a very suspicious city and without shame for the baseness of its suspicions .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: to a beggarThis is not thieving .

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: I could do no more , master . I have not practised thieving all my life .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: You have got something : it may serve our purpose . How long have you been thieving ?

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: I stole first when I was ten .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: in horrorWhen he was ten !

lg.l: We must tear them up and divide them amongst the seven .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: When my master was ten he had already to slip by night out of two cities .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: admiringlyOut of two cities ?

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: nodding his headIn his native city they do not now know what became of the golden cup that stood in the Lunar Temple .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Yes , into seven pieces .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: We will each wear a piece of it over our rags .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: Yes , yes , we shall look fine .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: That is not the way that we shall disguise ourselves .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: Not cover our rags ?

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: No , no . The first who looked closely would say , “ These are only beggars . They have disguised themselves . ”

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: What shall we do ?

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Each of the seven shall wear a piece of the green raiment underneath his rags . And peradventure here and there a little shall show through ; and men shall say , “ These seven have disguised themselves as beggars . But we know not what they be . ”

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: Hear my wise master .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: in admirationHe is a beggar .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: He is an old beggar .

div.stage: CURTAIN

div.head: THE SECOND ACT

stage.stage: The Metropolitan Hall of the city of Kongros . Citizens , etc .
Enter the seven beggars with green silk under their rags .

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: Who are you and whence come you ?

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Who may say what we are or whence we come ?

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: What are these beggars and why do they come here ?

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Who said to you that we were beggars ?

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: Why do these men come here ?

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Who said to you that we were men ?

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: Now , by the moon !

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: My sister .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: My little sister .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: Our little sister the moon . She comes to us at evenings away in the mountains of Marma . She trips over the mountains when she is young . When she is young and slender she comes and dances before us , and when she is old and unshapely she hobbles away from the hills .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Yet is she young again and forever nimble with youth ; yet she comes dancing back . The years are not able to curb her nor to bring gray hairs to her brethren .

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: This is not wonted .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: It is not in accordance with custom .

sp.speaker: AKMOS
sp.p: Prophecy hath not thought it .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: She comes to us new and nimble , remembering olden loves .

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: It were well that prophets should come and speak to us .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: This hath not been in the past . Let prophets come . Let prophets speak to us of future things .

div.stage: The beggars seat themselves upon the floor in the attitude of the seven gods of Marma .

sp.speaker: CITIZEN
sp.p: I heard men speak to-day in the market place . They speak of a prophecy read somewhere of old . It says the seven gods shall come from Marma in the guise of men .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: Is this a true prophecy ?

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: It is all the prophecy we have . Man without prophecy is like a sailor going by night over uncharted seas . He knows not where are the rocks nor where the havens . To the man on watch all things ahead are black and the stars guide him not , for he knows not what they are .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: Should we not investigate this prophecy ?

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: Let us accept it . It is as the small , uncertain light of a lantern , carried it may be by a drunkard , but along the shore of some haven . Let us be guided .

sp.speaker: AKMOS
sp.p: It may be that they are but benevolent gods .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: There is no benevolence greater than our benevolence .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: Then we need do little : they portend no danger to us .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: There is no anger greater than our anger .

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: Let us make sacrifice to them if they be gods .

sp.speaker: AKMOS
sp.p: We humbly worship you , if ye be gods .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: kneeling tooYou are mightier than all men and hold high rank among other gods and are lords of this our city , and have the thunder as your plaything and the whirlwind and the eclipse and all the destinies of human tribes — if ye be gods .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Let the pestilence not fall at once upon this city , as it had indeed designed to ; let not the earthquake swallow it all immediately up amid the howls of the thunder ; let not infuriated armies overwhelm those that escape — if we be gods —

sp.speaker: POPULACE
sp.p: in horrorIf we be gods !

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: Come , let us sacrifice .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: Bring lambs .

sp.speaker: AKMOS
sp.p: Quick ! Quick !Exeunt some

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: with solemn airThis god is a very divine god .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: He is no common god .

sp.speaker: MLAN
sp.p: Indeed he has made us .

sp.speaker: CITIZEN
sp.p: to SlagHe will not punish us , master ? None of the gods will punish us ? We will make a sacrifice , a good sacrifice .

sp.speaker: ANOTHER
sp.p: We will sacrifice a lamb that the priests have blessed .

sp.speaker: FIRST CITIZEN
sp.p: Master , you are not wroth with us ?

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: Who may say what cloudy dooms are rolling up in the mind of the eldest of the gods ? He is no common god like us . Once a shepherd went by him in the mountains and doubted as he went . He sent a doom after that shepherd .

sp.speaker: CITIZEN
sp.p: Master , we have not doubted .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: And the doom found him on the hills at evening .

sp.speaker: SECOND CITIZEN
sp.p: It shall be a good sacrifice , master .

div.stage: Reenter with a dead lamb and fruits . They offer the lamb on an altar where there is fire , and fruits before the altar .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: stretching out a hand to a lamb upon an altarThat leg is not being cooked at all .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: It is strange that gods should be thus anxious about the cooking of a leg of lamb .

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: It is strange certainly .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: Almost I had said that it was a man spoke then .

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: stroking his beard and regarding the second beggarStrange . Strange , certainly .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Is it then strange that the gods love roasted flesh ? For this purpose they keep the lightning . When the lightning flickers about the limbs of men there comes to the gods in Marma a pleasant smell , even a smell of roasting . Sometimes the gods , being pacific , are pleased to have roasted instead the flesh of lamb . It is all one to the gods ; let the roasting stop .

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: No , no , gods of the mountains !

sp.speaker: OTHERS
sp.p: No , no .

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: Quick , let us offer the flesh to them . If they eat , all is well .

div.stage: They offer it ; the beggars eat , all but Agmar , who watches .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: One who was ignorant , one who did not know , had almost said that they ate like hungry men .

sp.speaker: OTHERS
sp.p: Hush !

sp.speaker: AKMOS
sp.p: Yet they look as though they had not had a meal like this for a long time .

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: They have a hungry look .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: who has not eatenI have not eaten since the world was very new and the flesh of men was tenderer than now . These younger gods have learned the habit of eating from the lions .

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: O oldest of divinities , partake , partake .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: It is not fitting that such as I should eat . None eat but beasts and men and the younger gods . The sun and the moon and the nimble lightning and I — we may kill and we may madden , but we do not eat .

sp.speaker: AKMOS
sp.p: If he but eat of our offering he cannot overwhelm us .

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Oh , ancient deity , partake , partake .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Enough . Let it be enough that these have condescended to this bestial and human habit .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: to AkmosAnd yet he is not unlike a beggar whom I saw no so long since .

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: But beggars eat .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: Now I never knew a beggar yet who would refuse a bowl of Woldery wine .

sp.speaker: AKMOS
sp.p: This is no beggar .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: Nevertheless let us offer him a bowl of Woldery wine .

sp.speaker: AKMOS
sp.p: You do wrong to doubt him .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: I do but wish to prove his divinity . I will fetch the Woldery wine .Exit

sp.speaker: AKMOS
sp.p: He will not drink . Yet if he does , then he will not overwhelm us . Let us offer him the wine .

div.stage: Reenter Illanaun with a goblet .

sp.speaker: FIRST BEGGAR
sp.p: It is Woldery wine !

sp.speaker: SECOND BEGGAR
sp.p: It is Woldery !

sp.speaker: THIRD BEGGAR
sp.p: A goblet of Woldery wine !

sp.speaker: FOURTH BEGGAR
sp.p: O blessed day !

sp.speaker: MLAN
sp.p: O happy times !

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: O my wise master !

div.stage: Illanaun takes the goblet . All the beggars stretch out their hands including Agmar . Illanaun gives it to Agmar . Agmar takes it solemnly , and very carefully pours it upon the ground .

sp.speaker: FIRST BEGGAR
sp.p: He has spilt it .

sp.speaker: SECOND BEGGAR
sp.p: He has spilt it .Agmar sniffs the fumes , loquitur

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: It is a fitting libation . Our anger is somewhat appeased .

sp.speaker: ANOTHER BEGGAR
sp.p: But it was Woldery !

sp.speaker: AKMOS
sp.p: kneeling to AgmarMaster , I am childless , and I —

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Trouble us not now . It is the hour at which the gods are accustomed to speak to the gods in the language of the gods , and if Man heard us he would guess the futility of his destiny , which were not well for Man . Begone ! Begone !

sp.speaker: ONE LINGERS
sp.p: loquiturMaster —

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Begone !

div.stage: Exeunt . Agmar takes up a piece of meat and begins to eat it ; the beggars rise and stretch themselves : they laugh , but Agmar eats hungrily .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: Ah ! Now we have come into our own .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: Now we have alms .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: Master ! My wise master !

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: These are the good days , the good days ; and yet I have a fear .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: What do you fear ? There is nothing to fear . No man is as wise as my master .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: I fear the gods whom we pretend to be .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: The gods ?

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: taking a chunk of meat from his lipsCome hither , Slag .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: going up to himYes , master .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Watch in the doorway while I eat .Slag goes to the doorwaySit in the attitude of a god . Warn me if any of the citizens approach .

div.stage: Slag sits in the doorway in the attitude of a god , back to the audience .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: to AgmarBut , master , shall we not have Woldery wine ?

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: We shall have all things if only we are wise at first for a little .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: Master , do any suspect us ?

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: We must be very wise .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: But if we are not wise , master ?

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Why , then death may come to us —

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: O master !

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: — slowly .

div.stage: All stir uneasily except Slag , who sits motionless in the doorway .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: Do they believe us , master ?

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: half turning his headSomeone comes .

div.stage: Slag resumes his position .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: putting away his meatWe shall soon know now .

div.stage: All take up the attitude . Enter One , loquitur .

sp.speaker: ONE
sp.p: Master , I want the god that does not eat .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: I am he .

sp.speaker: ONE
sp.p: Master , my child was bitten in the throat by a death-adder at noon . Spare him , master ; he still breathes , but slowly .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Is he indeed your child ?

sp.speaker: ONE
sp.p: He is surely my child , master .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Was it your wont to thwart him in his play , while he was strong and well ?

sp.speaker: ONE
sp.p: I never thwarted him , master .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Whose child is Death ?

sp.speaker: ONE
sp.p: Death is the child of the gods .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Do you that never thwarted your child in his play ask this of the gods ?

sp.speaker: ONE
sp.p: with some horror , perceiving Agmar 's meaningMaster !

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Weep not . For all the houses that men have builded are the play-fields of this child of the gods .

div.stage: The Man goes away in silence , not weeping .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: taking Thahn by the wristIs this indeed a man ?

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: A man , a man , and until just now a hungry one .

div.stage: CURTAIN

div.head: THE THIRD ACT

sp.speaker: Same room
sp.p: A few days have elapsed . Seven thrones shaped like mountain-crags stand along the back of the stage . On these the beggars are lounging . The Thief is absent .

sp.speaker: MLAN
sp.p: Never had beggars such a time .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: Ah , the fruits and tender lamb !

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: The Woldery wine !

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: It was better to see my master 's wise devices than to have fruit and lamb and Woldery wine .

sp.speaker: MLAN
sp.p: Ah ! When they spied on him to see if he would eat when they went away !

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: When they questioned him concerning the gods and Man !

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: When they asked him why the gods permitted cancer !

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: Ah , my wise master !

sp.speaker: MLAN
sp.p: How well his scheme has succeeded !

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: How far away is hunger !

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: It is even like to one of last year 's dreams , the trouble of a brief night long ago .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: laughingHo , ho , ho ! To see them pray to us .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: When we were beggars did we not speak as beggars ? Did we not whine as they ? Was not our mien beggarly ?

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: We were the pride of our calling .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Then now that we are gods , let us be as gods , and not mock our worshippers .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: I think that the gods do mock their worshippers .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: The gods have never mocked us . We are above all pinnacles that we have ever gazed at in dreams .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: I think that when man is high then most of all are the gods wont to mock him .

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: enteringMaster ! I have been with those that know all and see all . I have been with the thieves , master . They know me for one of the craft , but they do not know me as being one of us .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Well , well !

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: There is danger , master , there is great danger .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: You mean that they suspect that we are men .

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: That they have long done , master . I mean that they will know it . Then we are lost .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Then they do not know it .

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: They do not know it yet , but they will know it , and we are lost .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: When will they know it ?

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: Three days ago they suspected us .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: More than you think suspected us , but have any dared to say so ?

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: No , master .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Then forget your fears , my thief .

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: Two men went on dromedaries three days ago to see if the gods were still at Marma .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: They went to Marma !

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: Yes , three days ago .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: We are lost !

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: They went three days ago ?

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: Yes , on dromedaries .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: They should be back to-day .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: We are lost !

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: We are lost !

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: They must have seen the green jade idols sitting against the mountains . They will say , “ The gods are still at Marma . ” And we shall be burnt .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: My master will yet devise a plan .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: to the ThiefSlip away to some high place and look toward the desert and see how long we have to devise a plan .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: My master will find a plan .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: He has taken us into a trap .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: His wisdom is our doom .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: He will find a wise plan yet .

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: reenteringIt is too late !

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: It is too late !

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: The dromedary men are here .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: We are lost !

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Be silent ! I must think .

div.stage: They all sit still . Citizens enter and prostrate themselves . Agmar sits deep in thought .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: to AgmarTwo holy pilgrims have gone to your sacred shrines , wherein you were wont to sit before you left the mountains .Agmar says nothingThey return even now .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: They left us here and went to find the gods ? A fish once took a journey into a far country to find the sea .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: Most reverend deity , their piety is so great that they have gone to worship even your shrines .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: I know these men that have great piety . Such men have often prayed to me before , but their prayers are not acceptable . They little love the gods ; their only care is their piety . I know these pious ones . They will say that the seven gods were still at Marma . They will lie and say that we were still at Marma . So shall they seem more pious to you all , pretending that they alone have seen the gods . Fools shall believe them and share in their damnation .

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: to IllanaunHush ! You anger the gods .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: I am not sure whom I anger .

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: It may be they are the gods .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: Where are these men from Marma ?

sp.speaker: CITIZEN
sp.p: Here are the dromedary men ; they are coming now .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: to AgmarThe holy pilgrims from your shrine are come to worship you .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: The men are doubters . How the gods hate the word ! Doubt ever contaminated virtue . Let them be cast into prison and not besmirch your purity .RisingLet them not enter here .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: But oh , most reverend deity from the Mountain , we also doubt , most reverend deity .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: You have chosen . You have chosen . And yet it is not too late . Repent and cast these men in prison and it may not be too late . The gods have never wept . And yet when they think upon damnation and the dooms that are withering a myriad bones , then almost , were they not divine , they could weep . Be quick ! Repent of your doubt .

div.stage: Enter the Dromedary Men .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: Most reverend deity , it is a mighty doubt .

sp.speaker: CITIZENS
sp.p: Nothing has killed him ! They are not the gods !

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: to AgmarYou have a plan , my master . You have a plan .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Not yet , Slag .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: to OoranderThese are the men that went to the shrines at Marma .

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: in a loud , clear voiceWere the Gods of the Mountain seated still at Marma , or were they not there ?

div.stage: The beggars get up hurriedly from their thrones .

sp.speaker: DROMEDARY MAN
sp.p: They were not there .

sp.speaker: ILLANAUN
sp.p: They were not there ?

sp.speaker: DROMEDARY MAN
sp.p: Their shrines were empty .

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: Behold the Gods of the Mountain !

sp.speaker: AKMOS
sp.p: They have indeed come from Marma .

sp.speaker: OORANDER
sp.p: Come . Let us go away to prepare a sacrifice . A mighty sacrifice to atone for our doubting .Exeunt

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: My most wise master !

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: No , no , Slag . I do not know what has befallen . When I went by Marma only two weeks ago the idols of green jade were still seated there .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: We are saved now .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: Ay , we are saved .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: We are saved , but I know not how .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: Never had beggars such a time .

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: I will go out and watch .He creeps out

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: Yet I have a fear .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: A fear ? Why , we are saved .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: Last night I dreamed .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: What was your dream ?

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: It was nothing . I dreamed that I was thirsty and one gave me Woldery wine ; yet there was a fear in my dream .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: When I drink Woldery wine I am afraid of nothing .

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: reenteringThey are making a pleasant banquet ready for us ; they are killing lambs , and girls are there with fruits , and there is to be much Woldery wine .

sp.speaker: MLAN
sp.p: Never had beggars such a time .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Do any doubt us now ?

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: I do not know .

sp.speaker: MLAN
sp.p: When will the banquet be ?

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: When the stars come out .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: Ah ! It is sunset already . There will be good eating .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: We shall see the girls come in with baskets upon their heads .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: There will be fruits in the baskets .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: All the fruits of the valley .

sp.speaker: MLAN
sp.p: Oh , how long we have wandered along the ways of the world !

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: Oh , how hard they were !

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: And how dusty !

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: And how little wine !

sp.speaker: MLAN
sp.p: How long we have asked and asked , and for how much !

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: We to whom all things are coming now at last !

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: I fear lest my art forsake me now that good things come without stealing .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: You will need your art no longer .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: The wisdom of my master shall suffice us all our days .

div.stage: Enter a frightened Man . He kneels before Agmar and abates his forehead .

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.p: Master , we implore you , the people beseech you .

div.stage: Agmar and the beggars in the attitude of the gods sit silent .

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.p: Master , it is terrible .The beggars maintain silenceIt is terrible when you wander in the evening . It is terrible on the edge of the desert in the evening . Children die when they see you .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: In the desert ? When did you see us ?

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.p: Last night , master . You were terrible last night . You were terrible in the gloaming . When your hands were stretched out and groping . You were feeling for the city .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Last night do you say ?

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.p: You were terrible in the gloaming !

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: You yourself saw us ?

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.p: Yes , master , you were terrible . Children too saw you and they died .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: You say you saw us ?

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.p: Yes , master . Not as you are now , but otherwise . We implore you , master , not to wander at evening . You are terrible in the gloaming . You are —

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: You say we appeared not as we are now . How did we appear to you ?

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.p: Otherwise , master , otherwise .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: But how did we appear to you ?

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.p: You were all green , master , all green in the gloaming , all of rock again as you used to be in the mountains . Master , we can bear to see you in flesh like men , but when we see rock walking it is terrible , it is terrible .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: That is how we appeared to you ?

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.p: Yes , master . Rock should not walk . When children see it they do not understand . Rock should not walk in the evening .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: There have been doubters of late . Are they satisfied ?

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.p: Master , they are terrified . Spare us , master .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: It is wrong to doubt . Go and be faithful .

div.stage: Exit Man .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: What have they seen , master ?

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: They have seen their own fears dancing in the desert . They have seen something green after the light was gone , and some child has told them a tale that it was us . I do not know what they have seen . What should they have seen ?

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: Something was coming this way from the desert , he said .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: What should come from the desert ?

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: They are a foolish people .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: That man 's white face has seen some frightful thing .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: A frightful thing ?

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: That man 's face has been near to some frightful thing .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: It is only we that have frightened them and their fears have made them foolish .

div.stage: Enter an Attendant with a torch or lantern which he places in a receptacle . Exit .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: Now we shall see the faces of the girls when they come to the banquet .

sp.speaker: MLAN
sp.p: Never had beggars such a time .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: Hark ! They are coming . I hear footsteps .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: The dancing girls ! They are coming !

sp.speaker: THIEF
sp.p: There is no sound of flutes , they said they would come with music .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: What heavy boots they have ; they sound like feet of stone .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: I do not like to hear their heavy tread . Those that would dance to us must be light of foot .

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: I shall not smile at them if they are not airy .

sp.speaker: MLAN
sp.p: They are coming very slowly . They should come nimbly to us .

sp.speaker: THAHN
sp.p: They should dance as they come . But the footfall is like the footfall of heavy crabs .

sp.speaker: ULF
sp.p: in a loud voice , almost chantingI have a fear , an old fear and a boding . We have done ill in the sight of the seven gods . Beggars we were and beggars we should have remained . We have given up our calling and come in sight of our doom . I will no longer let my fear be silent ; it shall run about and cry ; it shall go from me crying , like a dog from out of a doomed city ; for my fear has seen calamity and has known an evil thing .

sp.speaker: SLAG
sp.p: hoarselyMaster !

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: risingCome , come !

div.stage: They listen . No one speaks . The stony boots come on . Enter in single file through door in right of back , a procession of seven green men , even hands and faces are green ; they wear greenstone sandals ; they walk with knees extremely wide apart , as having sat cross-legged for centuries ; their right arms and right forefingers point upward , right elbows resting on left hands ; they stoop grotesquely . Halfway to the footlights they left wheel . They pass in front of the seven beggars , now in terrified attitudes , and six of them sit down in the attitude described , with their backs to the audience . The leader stands , still stooping .

sp.speaker: OOGNO
sp.p: cries out just as they wheel leftThe Gods of the Mountain !

sp.speaker: AGMAR
sp.p: hoarselyBe still ! They are dazzled by the light . They may not see us .The leading Green Thing points his forefinger at the lantern — the flame turns green . When the six are seated the leader points one by one at each of the seven beggars , shooting out his forefinger at them . As he does this each beggar in his turn gathers himself back on to his throne and crosses his legs , his right arm goes stiffly upward with forefinger erect , and a staring look of horror comes into his eyes . In this attitude the beggars sit motionless while a green light falls upon their faces . The gods go out .Presently enter the Citizens , some with victuals and fruit . One touches a beggar 's arm and then another 's .

sp.speaker: CITIZEN
sp.p: They are cold ; they have turned to stone .

div.stage: All abase themselves , foreheads to the floor .

sp.speaker: ONE
sp.p: We have doubted them . We have doubted them . They have turned to stone because we have doubted them .

sp.speaker: ANOTHER
sp.p: They were the true gods .

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: They were the true gods .

div.stage: CURTAIN

set.p: Scene : Outside the King 's great door in Zericon . Time : Some while before the fall of Babylon .

sp.speaker: THE GOLDEN DOOM
sp.p: Two Sentries pace to and fro , then halt , one on each side of the great door .

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: The day is deadly sultry .

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: I would that I were swimming down the Gyshon , on the cool side , under the fruit trees .

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: It is like to thunder or the fall of a dynasty .

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: It will grow cool by night-fall . Where is the King ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: He rows in his golden barge with ambassadors or whispers with captains concerning future wars . The stars spare him !

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: Why do you say “ the stars spare him ” ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: Because if a doom from the stars fall suddenly on a king it swallows up his people and all things round about him , and his palace falls and the walls of his city and citadel , and the apes come in from the woods and the large beasts from the desert , so that you would not say that a king had been there at all .

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: But why should a doom from the stars fall on the King ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: Because he seldom placates them .

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: Ah ! I have heard that said of him .

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: Who are the stars that a man should scorn them ? Should they that rule the thunder , the plague and the earthquake withhold these things save for much prayer ? Always ambassadors are with the King , and his commanders , come in from distant lands , prefects of cities and makers of the laws , but never the priests of the stars .

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: Hark ! Was that thunder ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: Believe me , the stars are angry .

body.stage: Enter a Stranger . He wanders toward the King 's door , gazing about him .

sp.speaker: SENTRIES
sp.p: lifting their spears at himGo back ! Go back !

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: It is death to touch the King 's door .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: I am a stranger from Thessaly .

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: It is death even for a stranger .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Your door is strangely sacred .

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: It is death to touch it .

body.stage: The Stranger wanders off .
Enter two children hand in hand .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: to the SentryI want to see the King to pray for a hoop .

body.stage: The Sentry smiles .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: pushes the door ; to girlI cannot open it .To the SentryWill it do as well if I pray to the King 's door ?

sp.speaker: SENTRY
sp.p: Yes , quite as well .Turns to talk to the other SentryIs there anyone in sight ?

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: shading his eyesNothing but a dog , and he far out on the plain .

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: Then we can talk awhile and eat bash .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: King 's door , I want a little hoop .

body.stage: The Sentries take a little bash between finger and thumb from pouches and put that wholly forgotten drug to their lips .

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: pointingMy father is a taller soldier than that .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: My father can write . He taught me .

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: Ho ! Writing frightens nobody . My father is a soldier .

lg.l: I have a lump of gold . I found it in the stream that runs down to

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: I have a poem . I found it in my own head .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Is it a long poem ?

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: No . But it would have been only there were no more rhymes for sky .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: What is your poem ?

lg.l: And it went up and up

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: I saw it die .

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: That does n't scan .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Oh , that does n't matter .

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: Do you like my poem ?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Birds are n't purple .

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: My bird was .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: Oh , you do n't like my poem !

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Yes , I do .

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: No , you do n't ; you think it horrid .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: No . I do n't .

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: Yes , you do . Why did n't you say you liked it ? It is the only poem I ever made .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: I do like it . I do like it .

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: You do n't , you do n't !

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Do n't be angry . I 'll write it on the door for you .

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: You 'll write it ?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Yes , I can write it . My father taught me . I 'll write it with my lump of gold . It makes a yellow mark on the iron door .

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: Oh , do write it ! I would like to see it written like real poetry .

body.stage: The Boy begins to write . The Girl watches .

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: You see , we 'll be fighting again soon .

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: Only a little war . We never have more than a little war with the hill-folk .

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: When a man goes to fight , the curtains of the gods wax thicker than ever before between his eyes and the future ; he may go to a great or to a little war .

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: There can only be a little war with the hill-folk .

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: Yet sometimes the gods laugh .

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: At whom ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: At kings .

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: Why have you grown uneasy about this war in the hills ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: Because the King is powerful beyond any of his fathers , and has more fighting men , more horses , and wealth that could have ransomed his father and his grandfather and dowered their queens and daughters ; and every year his miners bring him more from the opal-mines and from the turquoise-quarries . He has grown very mighty .

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: Then he will the more easily crush the hill-folk in a little war .

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: When kings grow very mighty the stars grow very jealous .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: I 've written your poem .

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: Oh , have you really ?

lg.l: Yes , I 'll read it to you .
And it went up and up

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: It does n't scan .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: That does n't matter .

body.stage: Enter furtively a Spy , who crosses stage and goes out . The Sentries cease to talk .

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: That man frightens me .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: He is only one of the King 's spies .

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: But I do n't like the King 's spies . They frighten me .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Come on , then , we 'll run away .

sp.speaker: SENTRY
sp.p: noticing the children againGo away , go away ! The King is coming , he will eat you .

body.stage: The Boy throws a stone at the Sentry and runs out . Enter another Spy , who crosses the stage . Enter third Spy , who notices the door . He examines it and utters an owl-like whistle . No . 2 comes back . They do not speak . Both whistle . No . 3 comes . All examine the door . Enter the King and his Chamberlain . The King wears a purple robe . The Sentries smartly transfer their spears to their left hands and return their right arms to their right sides . They then lower their spears until their points are within an inch of the ground , at the same time raising their right hands above their heads . They stand for some moments thus . Then they lower their right arms to their right sides , at the same time raising their spears . In the next motion they take their spears into their right hands and lower the butts to the floor , where they were before , the spears slanting forward a little . Both Sentries must move together precisely .

sp.speaker: FIRST SPY
sp.p: runs forward to the King and kneels , abasing his forehead to the floorSomething has written on the iron door .

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: On the iron door !

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Some fool has done it . Who has been here since yesterday ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: shifts his hand a little higher on his spear , brings the spear to his side and closes his heels all in one motion ; he then takes one pace backward with his right foot ; then he kneels on his right knee ; when he has done this he speaks , but not beforeNobody , Majesty , but a stranger from Thessaly .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Did he touch the iron door ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: No , Majesty ; he tried to , but we drove him away .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: How near did he come ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: Nearly to our spears , Majesty .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: What was his motive in seeking to touch the iron door ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: I do not know , Majesty .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Which way did he go ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: pointing leftThat way , Majesty , an hour ago .

body.stage: The King whispers with one of his Spies , who stoops and examines the ground and steals away . The Sentry rises .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: to his two remaining SpiesWhat does this writing say ?

sp.speaker: A SPY
sp.p: We cannot read , Majesty .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: A good spy should know everything .

sp.speaker: SECOND SPY
sp.p: We watch , Majesty , and we search out , Majesty . We read shadows , and we read footprints , and whispers in secret places . But we do not read writing .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: to the ChamberlainSee what it is .

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: goes up and readsIt is treason , Majesty .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Read it .

lg.l: And it went up and up

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: asideThe stars have spoken .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: to the SentryHas anyone been here but the stranger from Thessaly ?

sp.speaker: SENTRY
sp.p: kneeling as beforeNobody , Majesty .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: You saw nothing ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: Nothing but a dog far out upon the plain and the children of the guard at play .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: to the Second SentryAnd you ?

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: kneelingNothing , Majesty .

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: That is strange .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: It is some secret warning .

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: It is treason .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: It is from the stars .

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: No , no , Majesty . Not from the stars , not from the stars . Some man has done it . Yet the thing should be interpreted . Shall I send for the prophets of the stars ?

body.stage: The King beckons to his Spies . They run up to him .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Find me some prophet of the stars .Exeunt SpiesI fear that we may go no more , my chamberlain , along the winding ways of unequalled Zericon , nor play dahoori with the golden balls . I have thought more of my people than of the stars and more of Zericon than of windy Heaven .

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: Believe me , Majesty , some idle man has written it and passed by . Your spies shall find him , and then his name will be soon forgotten .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Yes , yes . Perhaps you are right , though the sentries saw no one . No doubt some beggar did it .

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: Yes , Majesty , some beggar has surely done it . But look , here come two prophets of the stars . They shall tell us that this is idle .

body.stage: Enter two Prophets and a Boy attending them . All bow deeply to the King . The two Spies steal in again and stand at back .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Some beggar has written a rhyme on the iron gate , and as the ways of rhyme are known to you I desired you , rather as poets than as prophets , to say whether there was any meaning in it .

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: ‘ Tis but an idle rhyme .

sp.speaker: FIRST PROPHET
sp.p: bows again and goes up to door . He glances at the writingCome hither , servant of those that serve the stars .

body.stage: Attendant approaches .

sp.speaker: FIRST PROPHET
sp.p: Bring hither our golden cloaks , for this may be a matter for rejoicing ; and bring our green cloaks also , for this may tell of young new beautiful things with which the stars will one day gladden the King ; and bring our black cloaks also , for it may be a doom .Exit the Boy ; the Prophet goes up to the door and reads solemnlyThe stars have spoken .

body.stage: Reenter Attendant with cloaks .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: I tell you that some beggar has written this .

sp.speaker: FIRST PROPHET
sp.p: It is written in pure gold .He dons the black cloak over body and head

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: What do the stars mean ? What warning is it ?

sp.speaker: FIRST PROPHET
sp.p: I cannot say .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: to Second ProphetCome you then and tell us what the warning is .

sp.speaker: SECOND PROPHET
sp.p: goes up to the door and readsThe stars have spoken .He cloaks himself in black

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: What is it ? What does it mean ?

sp.speaker: SECOND PROPHET
sp.p: We do not know , but it is from the stars .

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: It is a harmless thing ; there is no harm in it , Majesty . Why should not birds die ?

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Why have the prophets covered themselves in black ?

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: They are a secret people and look for inner meanings . There is no harm in it .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: They have covered themselves in black .

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: They have not spoken of any evil thing . They have not spoken of it .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: If the people see the prophets covered in black they will say that the stars are against me and believe that my luck has turned .

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: The people must not know .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Some prophet must interpret to us the doom . Let the chief prophet of the stars be sent for .

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: going toward left exitSummon the chief prophet of the stars that look on Zericon .

sp.speaker: VOICES OFF
sp.p: The chief prophet of the stars . The chief prophet of the stars .

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: I have summoned the chief prophet , Majesty .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: If he interpret this aright I will put a necklace of turquoises round his neck with opals from the mines .

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: He will not fail . He is a very cunning interpreter .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: What if he covers himself with a huge black cloak and does not speak and goes muttering away , slowly with bended head , till our fear spreads to the sentries and they cry aloud ?

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: This is no doom from the stars , but some idle scribe hath written it in his insolence upon the iron door , wasting his hoard of gold .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Not for myself I have a fear of doom , not for myself ; but I inherited a rocky land , windy and ill-nurtured , and nursed it to prosperity by years of peace and spread its boundaries by years of war . I have brought up harvests out of barren acres and given good laws unto naughty towns , and my people are happy , and lo , the stars are angry !

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: It is not the stars , it is not the stars , Majesty , for the prophets of the stars have not interpreted it . Indeed , it was only some reveller wasting his gold .

body.stage: Meanwhile enter Chief Prophet of the stars that look on Zericon .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Chief Prophet of the Stars that look on Zericon , I would have you interpret the rhyme upon yonder door .

sp.speaker: CHIEF PROPHET
sp.p: goes up to the door and readsIt is from the stars .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Interpret it and you shall have great turquoises round your neck , with opals from the mines in the frozen mountains .

sp.speaker: CHIEF PROPHET
sp.p: cloaks himself like the others in a great black cloakA pause .Who should wear purple in the land but a King , or who go up against the sky but he who has troubled the stars by neglecting their ancient worship ? Such a one has gone up and up increasing power and wealth , such a one has soared above the crowns of those that went before him , such a one the stars have doomed , the undying ones , the illustrious .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Who wrote it ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF PROPHET
sp.p: It is pure gold . Some god has written it .

sp.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
sp.p: Some god ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF PROPHET
sp.p: Some god whose home is among the undying stars .

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: aside to the Second SentryLast night I saw a star go flaming earthward .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Is this a warning or is it a doom ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF PROPHET
sp.p: The stars have spoken .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: It is , then , a doom ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF PROPHET
sp.p: They speak not in jest .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: I have been a great King — Let it be said of me “ The stars overthrew him , and they sent a god for his doom . ” For I have not met my equal among kings that man should overthrow me ; and I have not oppressed my people that man should rise up against me .

sp.speaker: CHIEF PROPHET
sp.p: It is better to give worship to the stars than to do good to man . It is better to be humble before the gods than proud in the face of your enemy though he do evil .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Let the stars hearken yet and I will sacrifice a child to them — I will sacrifice a girl child to the twinkling stars and a male child to the stars that blink not , the stars of the steadfast eyes .To his SpiesLet a boy and girl be brought for sacrifice .Exit a Spy to the right looking at footprintsWill you accept this sacrifice to the god that the stars have sent ? They say that the gods love children .

sp.speaker: CHIEF PROPHET
sp.p: I may refuse no sacrifice to the stars nor to the gods whom they send .To the other ProphetsMake ready the sacrificial knives .

body.stage: The Prophets draw knives and sharpen them .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Is it fitting that the sacrifice take place by the iron door where the god from the stars has trod , or must it be in the temple ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF PROPHET
sp.p: Let it be offered by the iron door .To the other ProphetsFetch hither the altar stone .

body.stage: The owl-like whistle is heard off right . The Third Spy runs crouching toward it . Exit .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Will this sacrifice avail to avert the doom ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF PROPHET
sp.p: Who knows ?

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: I fear that even yet the doom will fall .

sp.speaker: CHIEF PROPHET
sp.p: It were wise to sacrifice some greater thing .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: What more can a man offer ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF PROPHET
sp.p: His pride .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: What pride ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF PROPHET
sp.p: Your pride that went up against the sky and troubled the stars .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: How shall I sacrifice my pride to the stars ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF PROPHET
sp.p: It is upon your pride that the doom will fall , and will take away your crown and will take away your kingdom .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: I will sacrifice my crown and reign uncrowned amongst you , so only I save my kingdom .

sp.speaker: CHIEF PROPHET
sp.p: If you sacrifice your crown which is your pride , and if the stars accept it , perhaps the god that they sent may avert the doom and you may still reign in your kingdom though humbled and uncrowned .

docTitle.titlePart: KING Shall I burn my crown with spices and with incense or cast it into the sea ? CHIEF PROPHET Let it be laid here by the iron door where the god came who wrote the golden doom . When he comes again by night to shrivel up the city or to pour an enemy in through the iron door , he will see your cast-off pride and perhaps accept it and take it away to the neglected stars . KING ( to the Chamberlain )

stage.stage: Go after my spies and say that I make no sacrifice . ( Exit the Chamberlain to the right ; the King takes off his crown ) Good-bye , my brittle glory ; kings have sought you ; the stars have envied you . ( The stage grows darker )

sp.speaker: CHIEF PROPHET
sp.p: Even now the sun has set who denies the stars , and the day is departed wherein no gods walk abroad . It is near the hour when spirits roam the earth and all things that go unseen , and the faces of the abiding stars will be soon revealed to the fields . Lay your crown there and let us come away .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: lays his crown before the iron door ; then to the SentriesGo ! And let no man come near the door all night .

sp.speaker: THE SENTRIES
sp.p: kneelingYes , Majesty .

body.stage: They remain kneeling until after the King has gone . King and the Chief Prophet walk away .

sp.speaker: CHIEF PROPHET
sp.p: It was your pride . Let it be forgotten . May the stars accept it .Exeunt left

body.stage: The Sentries rise .

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: The stars have envied him !

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: It is an ancient crown . He wore it well .

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: May the stars accept it .

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: If they do not accept it what doom will overtake him ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: It will suddenly be as though there were never any city of Zericon nor two sentries like you and me standing before the door .

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: Why ! How do you know ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: That is ever the way of the gods .

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: But it is unjust .

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: How should the gods know that ?

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.p: Will it happen to-night ?

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.p: Come ! we must march away .Exeunt right

body.stage: The stage grows increasingly darker . Reenter the Chamberlain from the right . He walks across the Stage and goes out to the left . Reenter Spies from the right . They cross the stage , which is now nearly dark .

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: enters from the right , dressed in white , his hands out a little , cryingKing 's door , King 's door , I want my little hoop .He goes up to the King 's door . When he sees the King 's crown there , he utters a satisfiedO-oh !He takes it up , puts it on the ground , and , beating it before him with the sceptre , goes out by the way that he entered

body.stage: The great door opens ; there is light within ; a furtive Spy slips out and sees that the crown is gone . Another Spy slips out . Their crouching heads come close together .

sp.speaker: FIRST SPY
sp.p: hoarse whisperThe gods have come !

body.stage: They run back through the door and the door is closed . It opens again and the King and the Chamberlain come through .

docTitle.titlePart: KING The stars are satisfied . CURTAIN KING ARGIMENES AND THE UNKNOWN WARRIOR

castItem.role: THE SERVANT OF THE KING 'S DOG
KING ARGIMENES AND THE UNKNOWN WARRIOR

list.item: The dinner-hour on the slave-fields of King Darniak . King Argimenes is sitting upon the ground , bowed , ragged and dirty , gnawing a bone . He has uncouth hair and a dishevelled beard . A battered spade lies near him . Two or three slaves sit at back of stage eating raw cabbage-leaves . The tear-song , the chant of the low-born , rises at intervals , monotonous and mournful , coming from distant slave-fields .
This is a good bone ; there is juice in this bone .
I wish I were you , Argimenes .
I am not to be envied any longer . I have eaten up my bone .
I wish I were you , because you have been a king . Because men have prostrated themselves before your feet . Because you have ridden a horse and worn a crown and have been called Majesty .
When I remember that I have been a king it is very terrible .

But you are lucky to have such things in your memory as you have . I have nothing in my memory — Once I went for a year without being flogged , and I remember my cleverness in contriving it — I have nothing else to remember .
It is very terrible to have been a king .
But we have nothing who have no good memories in the past . It is not easy for us to hope for the future here .
We may not have a god because he might make us brave and we might kill our guards . He might make a miracle and give us swords .
Ah , you have no hope , then .
I have a little hope . Hush , and I will tell you a secret — The King 's great dog is ill and like to die . They will throw him to us . We shall have beautiful bones then .

Yes . That is what I hope for . And have you no other hope ? Do you not hope that your nation will arise some day and rescue you and cast off the king and hang him up by his thumbs from the palace gateway ?

No . I have no other hope , for my god was cast down in the temple and broken into three pieces on the day that they surprised us and took me sleeping . But will they throw him to us ? Will so honorable a brute as the King 's dog be thrown to us ?

body.head: ZARB
body.stage: When he is dead his honors are taken away . Even the King when he is dead is given to the worms . Then why should not his dog be thrown to us ?
We are not worms !

You do not understand , Argimenes . The worms are little and free , while we are big and enslaved . I did not say we were worms , but we are like worms , and if they have the King when he is dead , why then —
Tell me more of the King 's dog . Are there big bones on him ?
Ay , he is a big dog — a high , big , black one .
You know him then ?
Oh yes , I know him . I know him well . I was beaten once because of him , twenty-five strokes from the treble whips , two men beating me .
How did they beat you because of the King 's dog ?

They beat me because I spoke to him without making obeisance . He was coming dancing along over the slave-fields and I spoke to him . He was a friendly great dog , and I spoke to him and patted his head , and did not make obeisance .
And they saw you do it ?
Yes , the slave-guard saw me . They came and seized me at once and bound my arms . The great dog wanted me to speak to him again , but I was hurried away .
You should have made obeisance .
The great dog seemed so friendly that I forgot he was the King 's great dog .
But tell me more . Was he hurt or is it a sickness ?
They say that it is a sickness .

Ah , then he will grow thin if he does not die soon . If it had been a hurt !— but we should not complain . I complain more often than you do because I had not learned to submit while I was yet young .
If your beautiful memories do not please you , you should hope more . I wish I had your memories . I should not trouble to hope then . It is very hard to hope .
There will be nothing more to hope for when we have eaten the King 's dog .

Why , you might find gold in the earth while you were digging . Then you might bribe the commander of the guard to lend you his sword ; we would all follow you if you had a sword . Then we might take the King and bind him and lay him on the ground and fasten his tongue outside his mouth with thorns and put honey on it and sprinkle honey near . Then the gray ants would come from one of their big mounds . My father found gold once when he was digging .
KING ARGIMENES ( pointedly )
Did your father free himself ?
No . Because the King 's Overseer found him looking at the gold and killed him . But he would have freed himself if he could have bribed the guard .
[ A Prophet walks across the stage attended by two guards .
He is going to the King . He is going to the King .
He is going to the King .
Going to prophesy good things to the King . It is easy to prophesy good things to a king , and be rewarded when the good things come . What else should come to a king ? A prophet ! A prophet !

[ A deep bell tolls slowly . King Argimenes and Zarb pick up their spades at once , and the old slaves at the back of the stage go down on their knees immediately and grub in the soil with their hands . The white beard of the oldest trails in the dirt as he works . King Argimenes digs .
What is the name of that song that we always sing ? I like the song .
It has no name . It is our song . There is no other song .
Once there were other songs . Has this no name ?
I think the soldiers have a name for it .
What do the soldiers call it ?
The soldiers call it the tear-song , the chant of the low-born .
It is a good song . I could sing no other now .
[ Zarb moves away digging .
KING ARGIMENES ( to himself as his spade touches something in the earth )

Metal ! ( Feels with his spade again ) Gold perhaps !— It is of no use here . ( Uncovers earth leisurely . Suddenly he drops on his knees and works excitedly in the earth with his hands . Then very slowly , still kneeling , he lifts , lying flat on his hands , a long greenish sword , his eyes intent on it . About the level of his uplifted forehead he holds it , still flat on both hands , and addresses it thus ) O holy and blessed thing ! ( Then he lowers it slowly till his hands rest on his knees , and looking all the while at the sword , loquitur ) Three years ago to-morrow King Darniak spat at me , having taken my kingdom from me . Three times in that year I was flogged , with twelve stripes , with seventeen stripes , and with twenty stripes . A year and eleven months ago , come Moon-day , the King 's Overseer struck me in the face , and nine times in that year he called me dog . For one month two weeks and a day I was yoked with a bullock and pulled a rounded stone all day over the paths , except while we were fed . I was flogged twice that year — with eighteen stripes and with ten stripes . This year the roof of the slave-sty has fallen in and King Darniak will not repair it . Five weeks ago one of his Queens laughed at me as she came across the slave-fields . I was flogged again this year and with thirteen stripes , and twelve times they have called me dog . And these things they have done to a king , and a king of the House of Ithara . ( He listens attentively for a moment , then buries the sword again and pats the earth over it with his hands , then digs again )

[ The old slaves do not see him : their faces are to the earth . Enter the King 's Overseer carrying a whip . The slaves and King Argimenes kneel with their foreheads to the ground as he passes across the stage . Exit the King 's Overseer .
KING ARGIMENES ( kneeling , hands outspread downward )

O warrior spirit , wherever thou wanderest , whoever be thy gods , whether they punish thee or whether they bless thee , O kingly spirit , that once laid here this sword , behold , I pray to thee , having no gods to pray to , for the god of my nation was broken in three by night . Mine arm is stiff with three years ’ slavery , and remembers not the sword . But guide thy sword till I have slain six men and armed the strongest slaves , and thou shalt have the sacrifice every year of a hundred goodly oxen . And I will build in Ithara a temple to thy memory wherein all that enter in shall remember thee ; so shalt thou be honored and envied among the dead , for the dead are very jealous of remembrance . Ay , though thou wert a robber that took men 's lives unrighteously , yet shall rare spices smoulder in thy temple and little maidens sing and new-plucked flowers deck the solemn aisles ; and priests shall go about it ringing bells that thy soul shall find repose . Oh , but it has a good blade , this old green sword ; thou wouldst not like to see it miss its mark ( if the dead see at all , as wise men teach ) , thou wouldst not like to see it go thirsting into the air ; so huge a sword should find its marrowy bone . ( Extending his right hand upward ) Come into my right arm , O ancient spirit , O unknown warrior 's soul ! And if thou hast the ear of any gods , speak there against Illuriel , god of King Darniak . ( He rises and goes on digging )
THE KING 'S OVERSEER ( reentering )
So you have been praying .
KING ARGIMENES ( kneeling )
No , master .
The slave-guard saw you . ( Strikes him ) It is not lawful for a slave to pray .

I did but pray to Illuriel to make me a good slave , to teach me to dig well and to pull the rounded stone and to make me not to die when the food is scarce , but to be a good slave to my master the great King .
Who art thou to pray to Illuriel ? Dogs may not pray to an immortal god . ( Exit )
[ Zarb comes back , digging .
KING ARGIMENES ( digging )
Zarb !
ZARB ( also digging )
Do not look at me when you speak . The guards are watching us . Look at your digging .
How do the guards know we are speaking because we look at one another ?
You are very witless . Of course they know .
Zarb !
What is it ?
How many guards are there in sight ?
There are six of them over there . They are watching us .
Are there other guards in sight of these six guards ?
No .
How do you know ?
Because whenever their officer leaves them they sit upon the ground and play with dice .
How does that show that there are not another six in sight of them ?
How witless you are , Argimenes ! Of course it shows there are not . Because , if there were , another officer would see them , and their thumbs would be cut off .
Ah ! ( A pause ) Zarb ! ( A pause ) Would the slaves follow me if I tried to kill the guards ?
No , Argimenes .
Why would they not follow me ?
Because you look like a slave . They will never follow a slave , because they are slaves themselves , and know how mean a creature is a slave . If you looked like a king they would follow you .
But I am a king . They know that I am a king .
