It is better to look like a king . It is looks that they would go by .
If I had a sword would they follow me ? A beautiful huge sword of bronze .

I wish I could think of things like that . It is because you were once a king that you can think of a sword of bronze . I tried to hope once that I should some day fight the guards , but I could n't picture a sword , I could n't imagine it ; I could only picture whips .

Dig a little nearer , Zarb . ( They both edge closer ) I have found a very old sword in the earth . It is not a sword such as common soldiers wear . A king must have worn it , and an angry king . It must have done fearful things ; there are little dints in it . Perhaps there was a battle here long ago where all were slain , and perhaps that king died last and buried his sword , but the great birds swallowed him .
You have been thinking too much of the King 's dog , Argimenes , and that has made you hungry , and hunger has driven you mad .
I have found such a sword . [ A pause .
Why — then you will wear a purple cloak again , and sit on a great throne , and ride a prancing horse , and we shall call you Majesty .
I shall break a long fast first and drink much water , and sleep . But will the slaves follow me ?

You will make them follow you if you have a sword . Yet is Illuriel a very potent god . They say that none have prevailed against King Darniak 's dynasty so long as Illuriel stood . Once an enemy cast Illuriel into the river and overthrew the dynasty , but a fisherman found him again and set him up , and the enemy was driven out and the dynasty returned .
If Illuriel could be cast down as my god was cast down perhaps King Darniak could be overcome as I was overcome in my sleep ?
If Illuriel were cast down all the people would utter a cry and flee away . It would be a fearful portent .
How many men are there in the armory at the palace ?
There are ten men in the palace armory when all the slave-guards are out .
[ They dig awhile in silence .

The officer of the slave-guard has gone away — They are playing with dice now . ( He throws down his spade and stretches his arms ) The man with the big beard has won again , he is very nimble with his thumbs — They are playing again , but it is getting dark , I cannot clearly see .
[ King Argimenes furtively uncovers the sword , he picks it up and grips it in his hand .
Majesty !
[ King Argimenes crouches and steals away towards the slave-guard .
ZARB ( to the other slaves )
Argimenes has found a terrible sword and has gone to slay the slave-guard . It is not a common sword , it is some king 's sword .
Argimenes will be dreadfully flogged . We shall hear him cry all night . His cries will frighten us , and we shall not sleep .

No , no ! The guards flog poor slaves , but Argimenes had an angry look . The guards will be afraid when they see him look so angry and see his terrible sword . It was a huge sword , and he looked very angry . He will bring us the swords of the slave-guard . We must prostrate ourselves before him and kiss his feet or he will be angry with us too .
Will Argimenes give me a sword ?
He will have swords for six of us if he slays the slave-guard . Yes , he will give you a sword .
A sword ! No , no , I must not ; the King would kill me if he found that I had a sword .
SECOND SLAVE ( slowly , as one who develops an idea )
If the King found that I had a sword , why , then it would be an evil day for the King .
[ They all look off left .
I think that they are playing at dice again .
I do not see Argimenes .
No , because he was crouching as he walked . The slave-guard is on the sky-line .
What is that dark shadow behind the slave-guard ?
It is too still to be Argimenes .
Look ! It moves .
The evening is too dark , I cannot see .

[ They continue to gaze into the gathering darkness . They raise themselves on their knees and crane their necks . Nobody speaks . Then from their lips and from others farther off goes up a long , deep “ Oh ! ” It is like the sound that goes up from the grandstand when a horse falls at a fence , or , in England , like the first exclamation of the crowd at a great cricket match when a man is caught in the slips .

div.head: THE SECOND ACT

stage.stage: The Throne Hall of King Darniak . The King is seated on his throne in the centre at the back of the stage ; a little to his left , but standing out from the wall , a dark-green seated idol is set up . His Queens are seated about him on the ground , two on his right and two between him and the idol . All wear crowns . Beside the dark-green idol a soldier with a pike is kneeling upon one knee . The tear-song , the chant of the low-born , drifts faintly up from the slave-fields .

sp.speaker: FIRST QUEEN
sp.p: Do show us the new prophet , Majesty ; it would be very interesting to see another prophet .

sp.speaker: THE KING
sp.p: Ah , yes .

div.stage: He strikes upon a gong , and an Attendant enters , walks straight past the King and bows before the idol ; he then walks back to the centre of the stage and bows before the King .

sp.speaker: THE KING
sp.p: Bring the new prophet hither .

div.stage: Exit Attendant . Enter the King 's Overseer holding a roll of paper . He passes the King , bows to the idol , returns to the front of the King , kneels , and remains kneeling with bended head .

sp.speaker: THE KING
sp.p: speaking in the meanwhile to the Second Queen on his immediate rightWe are making a beautiful arbor for you , O Atharlia , at an end of the great garden . There shall be iris-flowers that you love and all things that grow by streams . And the stream there shall be small and winding like one of those in your country . I shall bring a stream a new way from the mountains .Turning to Queen Oxara on his extreme rightAnd for you , too , O Oxara , we shall make a pleasance . I shall have rocks brought from the quarries for you , and my idle slaves shall make a hill and plant it with mountain shrubs , and you can sit there in the winter thinking of the North .To the kneeling OverseerAh , what is here ?

sp.speaker: THE KING 'S OVERSEER
sp.p: The plans of your royal garden , Majesty . The slaves have dug it for five years and rolled the paths .

sp.speaker: THE KING
sp.p: takes the plansWas there not a garden in Babylon ?

sp.speaker: THE KING 'S OVERSEER
sp.p: They say there was a garden there of some sort , Majesty .

sp.speaker: THE KING
sp.p: I will have a greater garden . Let the world know and wonder .Looks at the plans

sp.speaker: THE KING 'S OVERSEER
sp.p: It shall know at once , Majesty .

sp.speaker: THE KING
sp.p: pointing at the planI do not like that hill , it is too steep .

sp.speaker: THE KING 'S OVERSEER
sp.p: No , Majesty .

sp.speaker: THE KING
sp.p: Remove it .

sp.speaker: THE KING 'S OVERSEER
sp.p: Yes , Majesty .

sp.speaker: THE KING
sp.p: When will the garden be ready for the Queens to walk in ?

sp.speaker: THE KING 'S OVERSEER
sp.p: Work is slow , Majesty , at this season of the year because the green stuff is scarce and the slaves grow idle . They even become insolent and ask for bones .

sp.speaker: QUEEN CAHAFRA
sp.p: to the King 's OverseerThen why are they not flogged ?To Queen ThragolindIt is so simple , they only have to flog them , but these people are so silly sometimes . I want to walk in the great garden , and then they tell me : “ It is not ready , Majesty . It is not ready , Majesty , ” as though there were any reason why it should not be ready .

sp.speaker: FOURTH QUEEN
sp.p: Yes , they are a great trouble to us .

div.stage: Meanwhile the King hands back the plans . Exit the King 's Overseer . Reenter Attendant with the Prophet , who is dressed in a long dark brown cloak ; his face is solemn ; he has a long dark beard and long hair . Having bowed before the idol , he bows before the King and stands silent . The attendant , having bowed to both , stands by the doorway .

sp.speaker: THE KING
sp.p: meanwhile to Queen AtharliaPerhaps we shall lure the ducks when the marshes are frozen to come and swim in your stream ; it will be like your own country .To the ProphetProphesy unto us .

sp.speaker: THE PROPHET
sp.p: speaks at once in a loud voiceThere was once a King that had slaves to hate him and to toil for him , and he had soldiers to guard him and to die for him . And the number of the slaves that he had to hate him and to toil for him was greater than the number of the soldiers that he had to guard him and to die for him . And the days of that King were few . And the number of thy slaves , O King , that thou hast to hate thee is greater than the number of thy soldiers .

sp.speaker: QUEEN CAHAFRA
sp.p: to Queen Thragolind— and I wore the crown with the sapphires and the big emerald in it , and the foreign prince said that I looked very sweet .

div.stage: The King , who has been smiling at Atharlia , gives a gracious nod to the Prophet when he hears him stop speaking . When the Queens see the King nod graciously , they applaud the Prophet by idly clapping their hands .

sp.speaker: THIRD QUEEN
sp.p: Do ask him to make us another prophecy , Majesty ! He is so interesting . He looks so clever .

sp.speaker: THE KING
sp.p: Prophesy unto us .

sp.speaker: THE PROPHET
sp.p: Thine armies camped upon thy mountainous borders descry no enemy in the plains afar . And within thy gates lurks he for whom thy sentinels seek upon lonely guarded frontiers . There is a fear upon me and a boding . Even yet there is time , even yet ; but little time . And my mind is dark with trouble for thy kingdom .

sp.speaker: QUEEN CAHAFRA
sp.p: to Queen ThragolindI do not like the way he does his hair .

sp.speaker: QUEEN THRAGOLIND
sp.p: It would be all right if he would only have it cut .

sp.speaker: THE KING
sp.p: to the Prophet , dismissing him with a nod of the headThank you , that has been very interesting .

sp.speaker: QUEEN THRAGOLIND
sp.p: How clever he is ! I wonder how he thinks of things like that ?

sp.speaker: QUEEN CAHAFRA
sp.p: Yes , but I hate a man who is conceited about it . Look how he wears his hair .

sp.speaker: QUEEN THRAGOLIND
sp.p: Yes , of course , it is perfectly dreadful .

sp.speaker: QUEEN CAHAFRA
sp.p: Why can n't he wear his hair like other people , even if he does say clever things ?

sp.speaker: QUEEN THRAGOLIND
sp.p: Yes , I hate a conceited man .1

div.stage: Footnote 1 : It is not necessary for the prophet 's hair to be at all unusual .
Enter an Attendant . He bows before the idol , then kneels to the King .

sp.speaker: THE ATTENDANT
sp.p: The guests are all assembled in the Chamber of Banquets .

div.stage: All rise . The Queens walk two abreast to the Chamber of Banquets .

sp.speaker: QUEEN ATHARLIA
sp.p: to Queen OxaraWhat was he talking about ?

sp.speaker: QUEEN OXARA
sp.p: He was talking about the armies on the frontier .

sp.speaker: QUEEN ATHARLIA
sp.p: Ah ! That reminds me of that young captain in the Purple Guard . They say that he loves Linoora .

sp.speaker: QUEEN OXARA
sp.p: Oh , Thearkos ! Linoora probably said that .

div.stage: When the Queens come to the doorway they halt on each side of it . Then they turn facing one another . Then the King leaves his throne and passes between them into the Chamber of Banquets , each couple courtseying low to him as he passes . The Queens follow , then the attendants . There rises the wine-song , the chant of the nobles , drowning the chant of the low-born . Only the Idol-Guard remains behind , still kneeling beside Illuriel .

sp.speaker: THE IDOL-GUARD
sp.p: I do not like those things the Prophet said — It would be terrible if they were true — It would be very terrible if they were false , for he prophesies in the name of Illuriel — Ah ! They are singing the wine-song , the chant of the nobles . The Queens are singing . How merry they are !— I should like to be a noble and sit and look at the Queens .He joins in the song

sp.speaker: THE VOICE OF A SENTINEL
sp.p: Guard , turn out .The wine-song still continues

sp.speaker: THE VOICE OF ONE HAVING AUTHORITY
sp.p: Turn out the guard there ! Wake up , you accursed pigs !

div.stage: Still the wine-song . A faint sound as of swords .

sp.speaker: A VOICE CRYING
sp.p: To the armory ! To the armory ! Reinforce ! The Slaves have come to the armory . Ah ! mercy !For awhile there is silence

sp.speaker: KING ARGIMENES
sp.p: in the doorwayGo you to the slave-fields . Say that the palace-guard is dead and that we have taken the armory . Ten of you , hold the armory till our men come from the slave-fields .He comes into the hall with his slaves armed with swordsThrow down Illuriel .

sp.speaker: THE IDOL-GUARD
sp.p: You must take my life before you touch my god .

sp.speaker: A SLAVE
sp.p: We only want your pike .

div.stage: All attack him ; they seize his sword and bind his hands behind him . They all pull down Illuriel , the dark-green idol , who breaks into seven pieces .

sp.speaker: KING ARGIMENES
sp.p: Illuriel is fallen and broken asunder .

sp.speaker: ZARB
sp.p: with some aweImmortal Illuriel is dead at last .

sp.speaker: KING ARGIMENES
sp.p: My god was broken into three pieces , but Illuriel is broken into seven . The fortunes of Darniak will prevail over mine no longer .A slave breaks off a golden arm from the throneCome , we will arm all the slaves .Exeunt

sp.speaker: KING DARNIAK
sp.p: enters with RetinueMy throne is broken . Illuriel is turned against me .

sp.speaker: AN ATTENDANT
sp.p: Illuriel is fallen .

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: with King DarniakIlluriel is fallen , is fallen .Some drop their spears

sp.speaker: KING DARNIAK
sp.p: to the Idol-GuardWhat envious god or sacrilegious man has dared to do this thing ?

sp.speaker: THE IDOL-GUARD
sp.p: Illuriel is fallen .

sp.speaker: KING DARNIAK
sp.p: Have men been here ?

sp.speaker: THE IDOL-GUARD
sp.p: Is fallen .

sp.speaker: KING DARNIAK
sp.p: What way did they go ?

sp.speaker: THE IDOL-GUARD
sp.p: Illuriel is fallen .

sp.speaker: KING DARNIAK
sp.p: They shall be tortured here before Illuriel , and their eyes shall be hung on a thread about his neck , so that Illuriel shall see it , and on their bones we will set him up again . Come !

div.stage: Those that have dropped their spears pick them up , but trail them along behind them on the ground . All follow dejectedly .

sp.speaker: VOICES OF LAMENTATION
sp.p: growing fainter and fainter offIlluriel is fallen , Illuriel is fallen . Illuriel , Illuriel , Illuriel . Is fallen . Is fallen .The song of the low-born ceases suddenly . Then voices of the slaves in the slave-fields chanting very loudlyIlluriel is fallen , is fallen , is fallen . Illuriel is fallen and broken asunder . Illuriel is fallen , fallen , fallen .

div.stage: Clamor of fighting is heard , the clash of swords , and voices , and now and then the name of Illuriel .

sp.speaker: THE IDOL-GUARD
sp.p: kneeling over a fragment of IllurielIlluriel is broken . They have overthrown Illuriel . They have done great harm to the courses of the stars . The moon will be turned to blackness or fall and forsake the nights . The sun will rise no more . They do not know how they have wrecked the world .

div.stage: Reenter King Argimenes and his men .

sp.speaker: KING ARGIMENES
sp.p: in the doorwayGo you to the land of Ithara and tell them that I am free . And do you go to the army on the frontier . Offer them death , or the right arm of the throne to be melted and divided amongst them all . Let them choose .The armed slaves go to the throne and stand on each side of it , loquiturMajesty , ascend your throne .King Argimenes , standing with his face toward the audience , lifts the sword slowly , lying on both his hands , a little above his head , then looking up at it , loquiturPraise to the unknown warrior and to all gods that bless him .He ascends the throne . Zarb prostrates himself at the foot of it and remains prostrated for the rest of the Act , muttering at intervals “ Majesty . ” An armed slave enters dragging the King 's Overseer . King Argimenes sternly watches him . He is dragged before the Throne . He still has the roll of parchment in his hand . For some moments King Argimenes does not speak . Then pointing at the parchmentWhat have you there ?

sp.speaker: THE KING 'S OVERSEER
sp.p: kneelingIt is a plan of the great garden , Majesty . It was to have been a wonder to the world .Unfolds it

sp.speaker: KING ARGIMENES
sp.p: grimlyShow me the place that I digged for three years .The King 's Overseer shows it with trembling hands ; the parchment shakes visiblyLet there be built there a temple to an Unknown Warrior . And let this sword be laid on its altar evermore , that the ghost of that Warrior wandering by nightif men do walk by night from across the gravemay see his sword again . And let slaves be allowed to pray there and those that are oppressed ; nevertheless the noble and the mighty shall not fail to repair there too , that the Unknown Warrior shall not lack due reverence .

div.stage: Enter , running , a Man of the household of King Darniak . He starts and stares aghast on seeing King Argimenes .

sp.speaker: KING ARGIMENES
sp.p: Who are you ?

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.p: I am the servant of the King 's dog .

sp.speaker: KING ARGIMENES
sp.p: Why do you come here ?

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.p: The King 's dog is dead .

sp.speaker: KING ARGIMENES AND HIS MEN
sp.p: savagely and hungrilyBones !

sp.speaker: KING ARGIMENES
sp.p: remembering suddenly what has happened and where he isLet him be buried with the late King .

sp.speaker: ZARB
sp.p: in a voice of protestMajesty !

div.stage: CURTAIN

set.p: Scene : A Lonely Place . Time : The present .

sp.speaker: THE GLITTERING GATE
sp.p: The Lonely Place is strewn with large black rocks and uncorked beer-bottles , the latter in great profusion . At back is a wall of granite built of great slabs , and in it the Gate of Heaven . The door is of gold . Below the Lonely Place is an abyss hung with stars . The rising curtain reveals Jim wearily uncorking a beer-bottle . Then he tilts it slowly and with infinite care . It proves to be empty . Faint and unpleasant laughter is heard off . This action and the accompanying far laughter are repeated continually throughout the play . Corked bottles are discovered lying behind rocks , and more descend constantly through the air , within reach of Jim . All prove to be empty . Jim uncorks a few bottles .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: weighing one carefullyThat 's a full one .It is empty , like all

body.stage: Singing is heard off left .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: enters from left with a bullet-hole over his eye , singingRule Britannia , Britannia rule the waves .Breaking off his songWhy , ‘ ullo . ‘ Ere 's a bottle of beer .Finds it empty ; looking off and downwardI 'm getting a bit tired of those blooming great stars down there and this rocky ledge . I 've been walking along under this wall ever since . Why , it must be twenty-four hours since that house-holder shot me . And he need n't have done it , either , I was n't going to hurt the bloke . I only wanted a bit of his silver stuff . It felt funny , that did . Hullo , a gate . Why , that 's the Gate of Heaven . Well , well . So that 's all right .Looks up and up for some timeNo . I can n't climb that wall . Why , it 's got no top to it . Up and up it goes .Knocks at the door and waits

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: That is n't for the likes of us .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Why , hullo , there 's another bloke . Why , somebody 's been hanging him . Why , if it is n't old Jim ! Jim !

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: wearilyHullo .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Why , Jim ! ‘ Ow long ‘ ave you been ‘ ere ?

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: I am ‘ ere always .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Why , Jim , do n't you remember me ? Why , you taught Bill to pick locks years and years ago when he was a little boy , and had never learnt a trade and had n't a penny in the world , and never would have had but for you , Jim .Jim stares vaguelyI never forgot you , Jim . I broke into scores of houses . And then I took on big houses . Out in the country , you know , real big ones . I got rich , Jim , and respected by all who knew me . I was a citizen , Jim , one who dwelt in our midst . And of an evening , sitting over the fire , I used to say , “ I am as clever as Jim . ” But I was n't , Jim . I could n't climb like you . And I could n't walk like you on a creaky stair , when everything 's quite still and there 's a dog in the house and little rattly things left lying about , and a door that whines if you touch it , and someone ill upstairs that you did n't know of , who has nothing to do but to listen for you ‘ cause she can n't get to sleep . Do n't you remember little Bill ?

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: That would be somewhere else .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes , Jim , yes . Down on Earth .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: But there is n't anywhere else .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I never forgot you , Jim . I 'd be pattering away with my tongue , in Church , like all the rest , but all the time I 'd be thinking of you in that little room at Putney and the man searching every corner of it for you with a revolver in one hand and a candle in the other , and you almost going round with him .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: What is Putney ?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Oh , Jim , can n't you remember ? Ca n't you remember the day you taught me a livelihood ? I was n't more than twelve , and it was spring , and all the may was in blossom outside the town . And we cleared out No . 25 in the new street . And next day we saw the man 's fat , silly face . It was thirty years ago .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: What are years ?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Oh , Jim !

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: You see there is n't any hope here . And when there is n't any hope there is n't any future . And when there is n't any future there is n't any past . It 's just the present here . I tell you we 're stuck . There are n't no years here . Nor no nothing .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Cheer up , Jim . You 're thinking of a quotation , “ Abandon hope , all ye that enter here . ” I used to learn quotations ; they are awfully genteel . A fellow called Shakespeare used to make them . But there is n't any sense in them . What 's the use of saying ye when you mean you ? Do n't be thinking of quotations , Jim .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: I tell you there is no hope here .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Cheer up , Jim . There 's plenty of hope there , is n't there ?Points to the Gate of Heaven

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: Yes , and that 's why they keep it locked up so . They wo n't let us have any . No . I begin to remember Earth again now since you 've been speaking . It was just the same there . The more they 'd got the more they wanted to keep you from having a bit .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You 'll cheer up a bit when I tell you what I 've got . I say , Jim , have you got some beer ? Why , so you have . Why , you ought to cheer up , Jim .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: All the beer you 're ever likely to see again . They 're empty .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: half rising from the rock on which he has seated himself , and pointing his finger at Jim as he rises ; very cheerfullyWhy , you 're the chap that said there was no hope here , and you 're hoping to find beer in every bottle you open .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: Yes ; I hope to see a drop of beer in one some day , but I know I wo n't . Their trick might not work just once .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How many have you tried , Jim ?

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: Oh , I do n't know . I 've always been at it , working as fast as I can , ever since — ever since —Feels his neck meditatively and up toward his earWhy , ever since , Bill .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Why do n't you stop it ?

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: I 'm too thirsty , Bill .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What do you think I 've got , Jim ?

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: I do n't know . Nothing 's any use .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: as yet another bottle is shown to be emptyWho 's that laughing , Jim ?

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: astonished at such a question , loudly and emphaticallyWho 's that laughing ?

p.stage: looks a little disconcerted at having apparently asked a silly question

lg.stage: The laugh off joins in loudly and for long

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well , I do n't know . But , Jim , what do you think I 've got ?

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: It is n't any good to you whatever it is . Not even if it is a ten-pound note .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It 's better than a ten-pound note , Jim . Jim , try and remember , Jim . Do n't you remember the way we used to go for those iron safes ? Do you remember anything , Jim ?

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: Yes , I am beginning to remember now . There used to be sunsets . And then there were great yellow lights . And one went in behind them through a swinging door .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes , yes , Jim . That was the Blue Bear down at Wimbledon .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: Yes , and the room was all full of golden light . And there was beer with light in it , and some would be spilt on the counter and there was light in that too . And there was a girl standing there with yellow hair . She 'd be the other side of that door now , with lamplight in her hair among the angels , and the old smile on her lips if one of them chaffed her , and her pretty teeth a-shining . She would be very near the throne ; there was never any harm in Jane .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No , there was never any ‘ arm in Jane , Jim .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: Oh , I do n't want to see the angels , Bill . But if I could see Jane againpoints in direction of laughhe might laugh as much as he cared to whenever I wanted to cry . You can n't cry here , you know , Bill .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You shall see her again , Jim .

body.stage: Jim takes no interest in this remark ; he lowers his eyes and goes on with his work .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Jim , you shall see her again . You want to get into Heaven , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: not raising his eyesWant !

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Jim . Do you know what I 've got , Jim ?

body.stage: Jim makes no answer , goes on wearily with his work .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You remember those iron safes , Jim , how we used to knock them open like walnuts with “ Old Nut-cracker ” ?

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: at work , wearilyEmpty again .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well , I 've got Old Nut-cracker . I had him in my hand at the time , and they let me keep him . They thought it would be a nice proof against me .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: Nothing is any good here .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I 'll get in to Heaven , Jim . And you shall come with me because you taught me a livelihood . I could n't be happy there , like those angels , if I knew of anyone being outside . I 'm not like that .

body.stage: Jim goes on with his work .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Jim , Jim . You 'll see Jane there .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: You 'll never get through those gates , Bill . You 'll never do it .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: They 're only gold , Jim . Gold 's soft like lead . Old Nut-cracker would do it if they were steel .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: You 'll never do it , Bill .

body.stage: Bill puts a rock against the gates , stands on it to reach the lock and gets to work on the lock . A good instrument to use is an egg-whipper . Jim goes on wearily with his work . As Bill works away , fragments and golden screws begin to fall on the floor .

lg.l: Jim ! Old Nut-cracker thinks nothing of it . It 's just like cheese to old

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: They wo n't let you do it , Bill .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: They do n't know what I 've got . I 'm getting through it like cheese , Jim .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: Suppose it 's a mile thick . Suppose it 's a million miles thick . Suppose it 's a hundred million miles thick .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Ca n't be , Jim . These doors are meant to open outward . They could n't do that if they were more than four inches at the most , not for an Archbishop . They 'd stick .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: You remember that great safe we broke open once , what had coal in it .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: This is n't a safe , Jim , this is Heaven . There 'll be the old saints with their halos shining and flickering , like windows o ’ wintry nights .Creak , creak , creakAnd angels thick as swallows along a cottage roof the day before they go .Creak , creak , creakAnd orchards full of apples as far as you can see , and the rivers of Tigris and Euphrates , so the Bible says ; and a city of gold , for those that care for cities , all full of precious stones ; but I 'm a bit tired of cities and precious stones .Creak , creak , creakI 'll go out into the fields where the orchards are , by the Tigris and the Euphrates . I should n't be surprised if my old mother was there . She never cared much for the way I earned my livelihoodcreak , creak, but she was a good mother to me . I do n't know if they want a good mother in there who would be kind to the angels and sit and smile at them when they sang and soothe them if they were cross . If they let all the good ones in she 'll be there all right .SuddenlyJim ! They wo n't have brought me up against her , will they ? That 's not fair evidence , Jim .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: It would be just like them to . Very like them .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: If there 's a glass of beer to be got in Heaven , or a dish of tripe and onions , or a pipe of ‘ bacca she 'll have them for me when I come to her . She used to know my ways wonderful ; and what I liked . And she used to know when to expect me almost anywhere . I used to climb in through the window at any hour and she always knew it was me .Creak , creakShe 'll know it 's me at the door now , Jim .Creak , creakIt will be all a blaze of light , and I 'll hardly know it 's her till I get used to it .... But I 'll know her among a million angels . There were n't none like her on Earth and there wo n't be none like her in Heaven .... Jim ! I 'm through , Jim ! One more turn , and old Nut-cracker 's done it ! It 's giving ! It 's giving ! I know the feel of it . Jim !

body.stage: At last there is a noise of falling bolts ; the gates swing out an inch and are stopped by the rock .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Jim ! Jim ! I 've opened it , Jim . I 've opened the Gate of Heaven ! Come and help me .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: looks up for a moment with open mouth . Then he mournfully shakes his head and goes on drawing a corkAnother one empty .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: looks down once into the abyss that lies below the Lonely PlaceStars . Blooming great stars .

body.stage: Then he moves away the rock on which he stood . The gates move slowly . Jim leaps up and runs to help ; they each take a gate and move backward with their faces against it .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hullo , mother ! You there ? Hullo ! You there ? It 's Bill , mother .

body.stage: The gates swing heavily open , revealing empty night and stars .

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: staggering and gazing into the revealed Nothing , in which far stars go wanderingStars . Blooming great stars . There ai n't no Heaven , Jim .

body.stage: Ever since the revelation a cruel and violent laugh has arisen off . It increases in volume and grows louder and louder .

sp.speaker: JIM
sp.p: That 's like them . That 's very like them . Yes , they 'd do that ! The curtain falls and the laughter still howls on .

sp.speaker: THE LOST SILK HAT
sp.p: The Caller stands on a doorstep , “ faultlessly dressed , ” but without a hat . At first he shows despair , then a new thought engrosses him .

body.stage: Enter the Laborer .

sp.speaker: THE CALLER
sp.p: Excuse me a moment . Excuse me — but — I 'd be greatly obliged to you if — if you could see your way — in fact , you can be of great service to me if —

sp.speaker: THE LABORER
sp.p: Glad to do what I can , sir .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Well , all I really want you to do is just to ring that bell and go up and say — er — say that you 've come to see to the drains , or anything like that , you know , and get hold of my hat for me .

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: Get hold of your ‘ at !

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Yes . You see , I left my hat behind most unfortunately . It 's in the drawing-roompoints to window, that room there , half under the long sofa , the far end from the door . And if you could possibly go and get it , why I 'd beThe Laborer 's expression changes— Why , what 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: firmlyI do n't like this job .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Do n't like this job ! But my dear fellow , do n't be silly , what possible harm —?

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: Ah-h. That 's what I do n't know .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: But what harm can there possibly be in so simple a request ? What harm does there seem to be ?

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: Oh , it seems all right .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Well , then .

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: All these crack jobs do seem all right .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: But I 'm not asking you to rob the house .

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: Do n't seem as if you are , certainly , but I do n't like the looks of it ; what if there 's things what I can n't ‘ elp taking when I gets inside ?

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: I only want my hat — Here , I say , please do n't go away — here 's a sovereign , it will only take you a minute .

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: What I want to know —

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: — Is what 's in that hat ?

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: What 's in the hat ?

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: Yes ; that 's what I want to know .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: What 's in the hat ?

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: Yes , you are n't going to give me a sovereign —?

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: I 'll give you two sovereigns .

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: You are n't going to give me a sovereign , and rise it to two sovereigns , for an empty hat ?

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: But I must have my hat . I can n't be seen in the streets like this . There 's nothing in the hat . What do you think 's in the hat ?

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: Ah , I 'm not clever enough to say that , but it looks as if the papers was in that hat .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: The papers ?

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: Yes , papers proving , if you can get them , that you 're the heir to that big house , and some poor innocent will be defrauded .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Look here , the hat 's absolutely empty . I must have my hat . If there 's anything in it you shall have it yourself as well as the two pounds , only get me my hat .

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: Well , that seems all right .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: That 's right , then you 'll run up and get it ?

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: Seems all right to me and seems all right to you . But it 's the police what you and I have got to think of . Will it seem all right to them ?

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Oh , for heaven 's sake —

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: Ah !

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: What a hopeless fool you are .

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: Ah !

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Look here .

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: Ah , I got you there , mister .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Look here , for goodness sake do n't go .

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: Ah !Exit

body.stage: Enter the Clerk .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Excuse me , sir . Excuse my asking you , but , as you see , I am without a hat . I shall be extraordinarily obliged to you if you would be so very good as to get it for me . Pretend you have come to wind the clocks , you know . I left it in the drawing-room of this house , half under the long sofa , the far end .

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Oh , er — all right , only —

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Thanks so much , I am immensely indebted to you . Just say you 've come to wind the clocks , you know .

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: I — er — do n't think I 'm very good at winding clocks , you know .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Oh , that 's all right , just stand in front of the clock and fool about with it . That 's all they ever do . I must warn you there 's a lady in the room .

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: But that 's all right , you know . Just walk past up to the clock .

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: But I think , if you do n't mind , as there 's someone there —

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Oh , but she 's quite young and very , very beautiful and —

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Why do n't you get it yourself ?

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: That is impossible .

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Impossible ?

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Yes , I have sprained my ankle .

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Oh ! Is it bad ?

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Yes , very bad indeed .

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: I do n't mind trying to carry you up .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: No , that would be worse . My foot has to be kept on the ground .

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: But how will you get home ?

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: I can walk all right on the flat .

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: I 'm afraid I have to be going on . It 's rather later than I thought .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: But for goodness sake do n't leave me . You can n't leave me here like this without a hat .

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: I 'm afraid I must , it 's later than I thought .

body.stage: Exit
Enter the Poet .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Excuse me , sir . Excuse my stopping you . But I should be immensely obliged to you if you would do me a very great favor . I have unfortunately left my hat behind while calling at this house . It is half under the long sofa , at the far end . If you could possibly be so kind as to pretend you have come to tune the piano and fetch my hat for me I should be enormously grateful to you .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: But why cannot you get it for yourself ?

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: I cannot .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: If you would tell me the reason perhaps I could help you .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: I cannot . I can never enter that house again .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: If you have committed a murder , by all means tell me . I am not sufficiently interested in ethics to wish to have you hanged for it .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Do I look like a murderer ?

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: No , of course not . I am only saying that you can safely trust me , for not only does the statute book and its penalties rather tend to bore me , but murder itself has always had a certain fascination for me . I write delicate and fastidious lyrics , yet , strange as it may appear , I read every murder trial , and my sympathies are always with the prisoner .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: But I tell you I am not a murderer .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: Then what have you done ?

lg.l: I have quarrelled with a lady in that house and have sworn to join the

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: But this is beautiful .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Unfortunately I forgot my hat .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: You go to die for a hopeless love , and in a far country ; it was the wont of the troubadours .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: But you will get my hat for me ?

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: That I will gladly do for you . But we must find an adequate reason for entering the house .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: You pretend to tune the piano .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: That , unfortunately , is impossible . The sound of a piano being unskilfully handled is to me what the continual drop of cold water on the same part of the head is said to be in countries where that interesting torture is practised . There is —

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: But what are we to do ?

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: There is a house where kind friends of mine have given me that security and comfort that are a poet 's necessity . But there was a governess there and a piano . It is years and years since I was able even to see the faces of those friends without an inward shudder .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Well , we 'll have to think of something else .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: You are bringing back to these unhappy days the romance of an age of which the ballads tell us that kings sometimes fought in no other armor than their lady 's nightshirt .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Yes , but you know first of all I must get my hat .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: But why ?

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: I cannot possibly be seen in the streets without a hat .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: It can n't be done .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: But you confuse externals with essentials .

lg.l: I do n't know what you call essentials , but being decently dressed in
London seems pretty essential to me .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: A hat is not one of the essential things of life .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: I do n't want to appear rude , but my hat is n't quite like yours .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: Let us sit down and talk of things that matter , things that will be remembered after a hundred years .They sitRegarded in this light one sees at once the triviality of hats . But to die , and die beautifully for a hopeless love , that is a thing one could make a lyric about . That is the test of essential things — try and imagine them in a lyric . One could not write a lyric about a hat .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: I do n't care whether you could write a lyric about my hat or whether you could n't . All I know is that I am not going to make myself absolutely ridiculous by walking about in London without a hat . Will you get it for me or will you not ?

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: To take any part in the tuning of a piano is impossible to me .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Well , pretend you 've come to look at the radiator . They have one under the window , and I happen to know it leaks .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: I suppose it has an artistic decoration on it .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Yes , I think so .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: Then I decline to look at it or to go near it . I know these decorations in cast iron . I once saw a pot-bellied Egyptian god , named Bes , and he was meant to be ugly , but he was n't as ugly as these decorations that the twentieth century can make with machinery . What has a plumber got to do with art that he should dare to attempt decoration ?

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Then you wo n't help me .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: I wo n't look at ugly things and I wo n't listen to ugly noises , but if you can think of any reasonable plan I do n't mind helping you .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: I can think of nothing else . You do n't look like a plumber or a clock-winder . I can think of nothing more . I have had a terrible ordeal and I am not in the condition to think calmly .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: Then you will have to leave your hat to its altered destiny .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Why can n't you think of a plan ? If you 're a poet , thinking 's rather in your line .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: If I could bring my thoughts to contemplate so absurd a thing as a hat for any length of time no doubt I could think of a plan , but the very triviality of the theme seems to scare them away .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: risingThen I must get it myself .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: For Heaven 's sake , do n't do that ! Think what it means !

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: I know it will seem absurd , but not so absurd as walking through London without it .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: I do n't mean that . But you will make it up . You will forgive each other , and you will marry her and have a family of noisy , pimply children like everyone else , and Romance will be dead . No , do n't ring that bell . Go and buy a bayonet , or whatever one does buy , and join the Bosnians .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: I tell you I can n't without a hat .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: What is a hat ! Will you sacrifice for it a beautiful doom ? Think of your bones , neglected and forgotten , lying forlornly because of hopeless love on endless golden sands . “ Lying forlorn ! ” as Keats said . What a word ! Forlorn in Africa . The careless Bedouins going past by day , at night the lion 's roar , the grievous voice of the desert .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: As a matter of fact , I do n't think you 're right in speaking of it as desert . The Bosnians , I believe , are only taking it because it is supposed to be the most fertile land in the world .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: What of that ? You will not be remembered by geography and statistics , but by golden-mouthed Romance . And that is how Romance sees Africa .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Well , I 'm going to get my hat .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: Think ! Think ! If you enter by that door you will never fall among the foremost Bosnians . You will never die in a far-off , lonely land to lie by immense Sahara . And she will never weep for your beautiful doom and call herself cruel in vain .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Hark ! She is playing the piano . It seems to me that she might be unhappy about it for years . I do n't see much good in that .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: No . I will comfort her .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: I 'm damned if you do ! Look here ! I do n't mind saying , I 'm damned if you do .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: Calm yourself . Calm yourself . I do not mean in that way .

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Then what on earth do you mean ?

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: I will make songs about your beautiful death , glad songs and sad songs . They shall be glad because they tell again the noble tradition of the troubadours , and sad because they tell of your sorrowful destiny and of your hopeless love . I shall make legends also about your lonely bones , telling perhaps how some Arabian men , finding them in the desert by some oasis , memorable in war , wonder who loved them . And then as I read them to her , she weeps perhaps a little , and I read instead of the glory of the soldier , how it overtops our transitory —

sp.speaker: CALLER
sp.p: Look here , I 'm not aware that you 've ever been introduced to her .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: A trifle , a trifle .

lg.l: It seems to me that you 're in rather an undue hurry for me to get a
Jubu spear in me ; but I 'm going to get my hat first .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: I appeal to you . I appeal to you in the name of beautiful battles , high deeds , and lost causes ; in the name of love-tales told to cruel maidens and told in vain . In the name of stricken hearts broken like beautiful harp-strings , I appeal to you . I appeal in the ancient holy name of Romance : do not ring that bell .

body.stage: Caller rings the bell .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: sits down , abjectYou will marry . You will sometimes take a ticket with your wife as far as Paris . Perhaps as far as Cannes . Then the family will come ; a large sprawling family as far as the eye can seeI speak in hyperboleYou 'll earn money and feed it and be like all the rest . No monument will ever be set up to your memory but —

body.stage: Servant answers bell . Caller says something inaudible . Exit through door .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: rising , lifting handBut let there be graven in brass upon this house : Romance was born again here out of due time and died young .He sits down

body.stage: Enter Laborer and Clerk with Policeman . The music stops .

sp.speaker: POLICEMAN
sp.p: Anything wrong here ?

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: Everything 's wrong . They 're going to kill Romance .

sp.speaker: POLICEMAN
sp.p: to LaborerThis gentleman does n't seem quite right somehow .

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: They 're none of them quite right to-day .

body.stage: Music starts again .

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: My God ! It is a duet .

sp.speaker: POLICEMAN
sp.p: He seems a bit wrong somehow .

sp.speaker: LABORER
sp.p: You should ‘ a seen the other one .

body.stage: CURTAIN
